story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: I had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: autumn of last year and found him in deep conversation with a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: With an apology for my intrusion, I was about to withdraw when

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Holmes pulled me abruptly into the room and closed the door

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: behind me.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "You could not possibly have come at a better time, my dear

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Watson," he said cordially.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "I was afraid that you were engaged."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "So I am. Very much so."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Then I can wait in the next room."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Not at all. This gentleman, Mr. Wilson, has been my partner and

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: helper in many of my most successful cases, and I have no

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: doubt that he will be of the utmost use to me in yours also."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: The stout gentleman half rose from his chair and gave a bob of

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: greeting, with a quick little questioning glance from his small

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: fat-encircled eyes.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Try the settee," said Holmes, relapsing into his armchair and

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: putting his fingertips together, as was his custom when in

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: judicial moods. "I know, my dear Watson, that you share my love

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: of all that is bizarre and outside the conventions and humdrum

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: routine of everyday life. You have shown your relish for it by

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the enthusiasm which has prompted you to chronicle, and, if you

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: will excuse my saying so, somewhat to embellish so many of my own

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: little adventures."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Your cases have indeed been of the greatest interest to me," I

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: observed.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "You will remember that I remarked the other day, just before we

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: went into the very simple problem presented by Miss Mary

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Sutherland, that for strange effects and extraordinary

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: combinations we must go to life itself, which is always far more

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: daring than any effort of the imagination."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "A proposition which I took the liberty of doubting."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "You did, Doctor, but none the less you must come round to my

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: view, for otherwise I shall keep on piling fact upon fact on you

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: until your reason breaks down under them and acknowledges me to

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: be right. Now, Mr. Jabez Wilson here has been good enough to call

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: upon me this morning, and to begin a narrative which promises to

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: be one of the most singular which I have listened to for some

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: time. You have heard me remark that the strangest and most unique

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: things are very often connected not with the larger but with the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: smaller crimes, and occasionally, indeed, where there is room for

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: doubt whether any positive crime has been committed. As far as I

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: have heard it is impossible for me to say whether the present

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: case is an instance of crime or not, but the course of events is

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: certainly among the most singular that I have ever listened to.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Perhaps, Mr. Wilson, you would have the great kindness to

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: recommence your narrative. I ask you not merely because my friend

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Dr. Watson has not heard the opening part but also because the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: peculiar nature of the story makes me anxious to have every

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: possible detail from your lips. As a rule, when I have heard some

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: slight indication of the course of events, I am able to guide

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: myself by the thousands of other similar cases which occur to my

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: memory. In the present instance I am forced to admit that the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: facts are, to the best of my belief, unique."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: The portly client puffed out his chest with an appearance of some

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: little pride and pulled a dirty and wrinkled newspaper from the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: inside pocket of his greatcoat. As he glanced down the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: flattened out upon his knee, I took a good look at the man and

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: indications which might be presented by his dress or appearance.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: I did not gain very much, however, by my inspection. Our visitor

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: bore every mark of being an average commonplace British

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: tradesman, obese, pompous, and slow. He wore rather baggy grey

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: shepherd's check trousers, a not over-clean black frock-coat,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: unbuttoned in the front, and a drab waistcoat with a heavy brassy

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Albert chain, and a square pierced bit of metal dangling down as

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: an ornament. A frayed top-hat and a faded brown overcoat with a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: wrinkled velvet collar lay upon a chair beside him. Altogether,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: look as I would, there was nothing remarkable about the man save

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: his blazing red head, and the expression of extreme chagrin and

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: discontent upon his features.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Sherlock Holmes' quick eye took in my occupation, and he shook

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: his head with a smile as he noticed my questioning glances.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Beyond the obvious facts that he has at some time done manual

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: labour, that he takes snuff, that he is a Freemason, that he has

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: been in China, and that he has done a considerable amount of

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: writing lately, I can deduce nothing else."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Mr. Jabez Wilson started up in his chair, with his forefinger

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: upon the paper, but his eyes upon my companion.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "How, in the name of good-fortune, did you know all that, Mr.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Holmes?" he asked. "How did you know, for example, that I did

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: manual labour. It's as true as gospel, for I began as a ship's

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: carpenter."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Your hands, my dear sir. Your right hand is quite a size larger

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: than your left. You have worked with it, and the muscles are more

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: developed."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: my assistant, hardly knowing what to say or do, I was so pleased

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Well, I thought over the matter all day, and by evening I was in

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: low spirits again; for I had quite persuaded myself that the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: whole affair must be some great hoax or fraud, though what its

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: object might be I could not imagine. It seemed altogether past

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: belief that anyone could make such a will, or that they would pay

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: such a sum for doing anything so simple as copying out the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: 'Encyclopaedia Britannica.' Vincent Spaulding did what he could to

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: cheer me up, but by bedtime I had reasoned myself out of the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: whole thing. However, in the morning I determined to have a look

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: at it anyhow, so I bought a penny bottle of ink, and with a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: quill-pen, and seven sheets of foolscap paper, I started off for

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Pope's Court.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Well, to my surprise and delight, everything was as right as

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: was there to see that I got fairly to work. He started me off

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: upon the letter A, and then he left me; but he would drop in from

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: time to time to see that all was right with me. At two o'clock he

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: bade me good-day, complimented me upon the amount that I had

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: written, and locked the door of the office after me.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "This went on day after day, Mr. Holmes, and on Saturday the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: week's work. It was the same next week, and the same the week

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: after. Every morning I was there at ten, and every afternoon I

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: left at two. By degrees Mr. Duncan Ross took to coming in only

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: once of a morning, and then, after a time, he did not come in at

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: all. Still, of course, I never dared to leave the room for an

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: instant, for I was not sure when he might come, and the billet

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: was such a good one, and suited me so well, that I would not risk

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the loss of it.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Eight weeks passed away like this, and I had written about

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: business came to an end."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "My dear doctor, this is a time for observation, not for talk. We

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: are spies in an enemy's country. We know something of Saxe-Coburg

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Square. Let us now explore the parts which lie behind it."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: The road in which we found ourselves as we turned round the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: corner from the retired Saxe-Coburg Square presented as great a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: contrast to it as the front of a picture does to the back. It was

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: one of the main arteries which conveyed the traffic of the City

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: to the north and west. The roadway was blocked with the immense

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: stream of commerce flowing in a double tide inward and outward,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: while the footpaths were black with the hurrying swarm of

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: pedestrians. It was difficult to realise as we looked at the line

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: of fine shops and stately business premises that they really

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: abutted on the other side upon the faded and stagnant square

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: which we had just quitted.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Let me see," said Holmes, standing at the corner and glancing

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: along the line, "I should like just to remember the order of the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: houses here. It is a hobby of mine to have an exact knowledge of

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: London. There is Mortimer's, the tobacconist, the little

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: newspaper shop, the Coburg branch of the City and Suburban Bank,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the Vegetarian Restaurant, and McFarlane's carriage-building

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: depot. That carries us right on to the other block. And now,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Doctor, we've done our work, so it's time we had some play. A

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: sandwich and a cup of coffee, and then off to violin-land, where

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: all is sweetness and delicacy and harmony, and there are no

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: red-headed clients to vex us with their conundrums."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: My friend was an enthusiastic musician, being himself not only a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: very capable performer but a composer of no ordinary merit. All

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the afternoon he sat in the stalls wrapped in the most perfect

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: happiness, gently waving his long, thin fingers in time to the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: music, while his gently smiling face and his languid, dreamy eyes

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: were as unlike those of Holmes the sleuth-hound, Holmes the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: relentless, keen-witted, ready-handed criminal agent, as it was

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: possible to conceive. In his singular character the dual nature

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: alternately asserted itself, and his extreme exactness and

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: astuteness represented, as I have often thought, the reaction

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: against the poetic and contemplative mood which occasionally

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: predominated in him. The swing of his nature took him from

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: extreme languor to devouring energy; and, as I knew well, he was

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: never so truly formidable as when, for days on end, he had been

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: lounging in his armchair amid his improvisations and his

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: black-letter editions. Then it was that the lust of the chase

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: would suddenly come upon him, and that his brilliant reasoning

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: power would rise to the level of intuition, until those who were

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: unacquainted with his methods would look askance at him as on a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: man whose knowledge was not that of other mortals. When I saw him

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: that afternoon so enwrapped in the music at St. James's Hall I

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: felt that an evil time might be coming upon those whom he had set

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: himself to hunt down.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "You want to go home, no doubt, Doctor," he remarked as we

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: emerged.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Yes, it would be as well."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "And I have some business to do which will take some hours. This

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: business at Coburg Square is serious."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Why serious?"

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "A considerable crime is in contemplation. I have every reason to

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: believe that we shall be in time to stop it. But to-day being

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Saturday rather complicates matters. I shall want your help

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: to-night."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "At what time?"

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Ten will be early enough."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "I shall be at Baker Street at ten."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Very well. And, I say, Doctor, there may be some little danger,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: so kindly put your army revolver in your pocket." He waved his

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: hand, turned on his heel, and disappeared in an instant among the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: crowd.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: I trust that I am not more dense than my neighbours, but I was

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: always oppressed with a sense of my own stupidity in my dealings

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: with Sherlock Holmes. Here I had heard what he had heard, I had

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: seen what he had seen, and yet from his words it was evident that

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: he saw clearly not only what had happened but what was about to

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: happen, while to me the whole business was still confused and

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: grotesque. As I drove home to my house in Kensington I thought

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: over it all, from the extraordinary story of the red-headed

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: copier of the "Encyclopaedia" down to the visit to Saxe-Coburg

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Square, and the ominous words with which he had parted from me.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: What was this nocturnal expedition, and why should I go armed?

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Where were we going, and what were we to do? I had the hint from

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Holmes that this smooth-faced pawnbroker's assistant was a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: formidable man--a man who might play a deep game. I tried to

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: puzzle it out, but gave it up in despair and set the matter aside

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: until night should bring an explanation.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: It was a quarter-past nine when I started from home and made my

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: way across the Park, and so through Oxford Street to Baker

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Street. Two hansoms were standing at the door, and as I entered

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the passage I heard the sound of voices from above. On entering

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: his room I found Holmes in animated conversation with two men,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: one of whom I recognised as Peter Jones, the official police

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: agent, while the other was a long, thin, sad-faced man, with a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: very shiny hat and oppressively respectable frock-coat.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Ha! Our party is complete," said Holmes, buttoning up his

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: pea-jacket and taking his heavy hunting crop from the rack.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Watson, I think you know Mr. Jones, of Scotland Yard? Let me

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: introduce you to Mr. Merryweather, who is to be our companion in

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: to-night's adventure."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "We're hunting in couples again, Doctor, you see," said Jones in

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: his consequential way. "Our friend here is a wonderful man for

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: starting a chase. All he wants is an old dog to help him to do

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the running down."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "I hope a wild goose may not prove to be the end of our chase,"

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: observed Mr. Merryweather gloomily.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "You may place considerable confidence in Mr. Holmes, sir," said

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the police agent loftily. "He has his own little methods, which

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: are, if he won't mind my saying so, just a little too theoretical

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: and fantastic, but he has the makings of a detective in him. It

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: is not too much to say that once or twice, as in that business of

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the Sholto murder and the Agra treasure, he has been more nearly

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: correct than the official force."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "Oh, if you say so, Mr. Jones, it is all right," said the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: stranger with deference. "Still, I confess that I miss my rubber.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: It is the first Saturday night for seven-and-twenty years that I

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: have not had my rubber."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "I think you will find," said Sherlock Holmes, "that you will

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: play for a higher stake to-night than you have ever done yet, and

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: that the play will be more exciting. For you, Mr. Merryweather,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the stake will be some 30,000 pounds; and for you, Jones, it will

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: be the man upon whom you wish to lay your hands."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "John Clay, the murderer, thief, smasher, and forger. He's a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: young man, Mr. Merryweather, but he is at the head of his

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: profession, and I would rather have my bracelets on him than on

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: any criminal in London. He's a remarkable man, is young John

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Clay. His grandfather was a royal duke, and he himself has been

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: to Eton and Oxford. His brain is as cunning as his fingers, and

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: though we meet signs of him at every turn, we never know where to

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: find the man himself. He'll crack a crib in Scotland one week,

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: and be raising money to build an orphanage in Cornwall the next.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: I've been on his track for years and have never set eyes on him

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: yet."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "I hope that I may have the pleasure of introducing you to-night.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: I've had one or two little turns also with Mr. John Clay, and I

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: agree with you that he is at the head of his profession. It is

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: past ten, however, and quite time that we started. If you two

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: will take the first hansom, Watson and I will follow in the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: second."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: and lay back in the cab humming the tunes which he had heard in

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: the afternoon. We rattled through an endless labyrinth of gas-lit

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: streets until we emerged into Farrington Street.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: "We are close there now," my friend remarked. "This fellow

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Merryweather is a bank director, and personally interested in the

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: matter. I thought it as well to have Jones with us also. He is

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: not a bad fellow, though an absolute imbecile in his profession.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: He has one positive virtue. He is as brave as a bulldog and as

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: tenacious as a lobster if he gets his claws upon anyone. Here we

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: are, and they are waiting for us."

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

text: following the guidance of Mr. Merryweather, we passed down a

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: narrow passage and through a side door, which he opened for us.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Within there was a small corridor, which ended in a very massive

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: iron gate. This also was opened, and led down a flight of winding

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: stone steps, which terminated at another formidable gate. Mr.

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE
text: Merryweather stopped to light a lantern, and then conducted us

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE II. THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

story: ADVENTURE III. A CASE OF IDENTITY

text: held, that of Hatherley, was let to Mr. Charles McCarthy, who was

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: also an ex-Australian. The men had known each other in the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: colonies, so that it was not unnatural that when they came to

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: settle down they should do so as near each other as possible.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Turner was apparently the richer man, so McCarthy became his

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: tenant but still remained, it seems, upon terms of perfect

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: equality, as they were frequently together. McCarthy had one son,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: a lad of eighteen, and Turner had an only daughter of the same

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: age, but neither of them had wives living. They appear to have

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: avoided the society of the neighbouring English families and to

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: have led retired lives, though both the McCarthys were fond of

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: sport and were frequently seen at the race-meetings of the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: neighbourhood. McCarthy kept two servants--a man and a girl.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Turner had a considerable household, some half-dozen at the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: least. That is as much as I have been able to gather about the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: families. Now for the facts.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "On June 3rd, that is, on Monday last, McCarthy left his house at

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Hatherley about three in the afternoon and walked down to the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Boscombe Pool, which is a small lake formed by the spreading out

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: of the stream which runs down the Boscombe Valley. He had been

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: out with his serving-man in the morning at Ross, and he had told

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the man that he must hurry, as he had an appointment of

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: importance to keep at three. From that appointment he never came

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: back alive.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "From Hatherley Farm-house to the Boscombe Pool is a quarter of a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: mile, and two people saw him as he passed over this ground. One

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: was an old woman, whose name is not mentioned, and the other was

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: William Crowder, a game-keeper in the employ of Mr. Turner. Both

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: these witnesses depose that Mr. McCarthy was walking alone. The

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: game-keeper adds that within a few minutes of his seeing Mr.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: McCarthy pass he had seen his son, Mr. James McCarthy, going the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: same way with a gun under his arm. To the best of his belief, the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: father was actually in sight at the time, and the son was

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: following him. He thought no more of the matter until he heard in

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the evening of the tragedy that had occurred.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The two McCarthys were seen after the time when William Crowder,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the game-keeper, lost sight of them. The Boscombe Pool is thickly

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: wooded round, with just a fringe of grass and of reeds round the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: edge. A girl of fourteen, Patience Moran, who is the daughter of

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the lodge-keeper of the Boscombe Valley estate, was in one of the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: woods picking flowers. She states that while she was there she

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: saw, at the border of the wood and close by the lake, Mr.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: McCarthy and his son, and that they appeared to be having a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: violent quarrel. She heard Mr. McCarthy the elder using very

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: strong language to his son, and she saw the latter raise up his

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: hand as if to strike his father. She was so frightened by their

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: violence that she ran away and told her mother when she reached

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: home that she had left the two McCarthys quarrelling near

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Boscombe Pool, and that she was afraid that they were going to

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: fight. She had hardly said the words when young Mr. McCarthy came

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: running up to the lodge to say that he had found his father dead

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: in the wood, and to ask for the help of the lodge-keeper. He was

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: much excited, without either his gun or his hat, and his right

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: hand and sleeve were observed to be stained with fresh blood. On

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: following him they found the dead body stretched out upon the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: grass beside the pool. The head had been beaten in by repeated

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: blows of some heavy and blunt weapon. The injuries were such as

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: might very well have been inflicted by the butt-end of his son's

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: gun, which was found lying on the grass within a few paces of the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: body. Under these circumstances the young man was instantly

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: arrested, and a verdict of 'wilful murder' having been returned

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: at the inquest on Tuesday, he was on Wednesday brought before the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: magistrates at Ross, who have referred the case to the next

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Assizes. Those are the main facts of the case as they came out

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: before the coroner and the police-court."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I could hardly imagine a more damning case," I remarked. "If

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: ever circumstantial evidence pointed to a criminal it does so

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: here."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Circumstantial evidence is a very tricky thing," answered Holmes

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: thoughtfully. "It may seem to point very straight to one thing,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: but if you shift your own point of view a little, you may find it

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: pointing in an equally uncompromising manner to something

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: entirely different. It must be confessed, however, that the case

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: looks exceedingly grave against the young man, and it is very

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: possible that he is indeed the culprit. There are several people

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: in the neighbourhood, however, and among them Miss Turner, the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: daughter of the neighbouring landowner, who believe in his

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: innocence, and who have retained Lestrade, whom you may recollect

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: in connection with the Study in Scarlet, to work out the case in

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: his interest. Lestrade, being rather puzzled, has referred the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: case to me, and hence it is that two middle-aged gentlemen are

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: flying westward at fifty miles an hour instead of quietly

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: digesting their breakfasts at home."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I am afraid," said I, "that the facts are so obvious that you

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: will find little credit to be gained out of this case."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "There is nothing more deceptive than an obvious fact," he

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: answered, laughing. "Besides, we may chance to hit upon some

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: other obvious facts which may have been by no means obvious to

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Mr. Lestrade. You know me too well to think that I am boasting

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: when I say that I shall either confirm or destroy his theory by

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: means which he is quite incapable of employing, or even of

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: understanding. To take the first example to hand, I very clearly

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: perceive that in your bedroom the window is upon the right-hand

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: side, and yet I question whether Mr. Lestrade would have noted

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: even so self-evident a thing as that."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "How on earth--"

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "My dear fellow, I know you well. I know the military neatness

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: which characterises you. You shave every morning, and in this

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: season you shave by the sunlight; but since your shaving is less

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: and less complete as we get farther back on the left side, until

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: it becomes positively slovenly as we get round the angle of the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: jaw, it is surely very clear that that side is less illuminated

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: than the other. I could not imagine a man of your habits looking

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: at himself in an equal light and being satisfied with such a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: result. I only quote this as a trivial example of observation and

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: inference. Therein lies my metier, and it is just possible that

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: it may be of some service in the investigation which lies before

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: us. There are one or two minor points which were brought out in

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the inquest, and which are worth considering."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "What are they?"

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "It appears that his arrest did not take place at once, but after

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the return to Hatherley Farm. On the inspector of constabulary

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: informing him that he was a prisoner, he remarked that he was not

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: surprised to hear it, and that it was no more than his deserts.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: This observation of his had the natural effect of removing any

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: traces of doubt which might have remained in the minds of the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: coroner's jury."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "It was a confession," I ejaculated.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "No, for it was followed by a protestation of innocence."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Coming on the top of such a damning series of events, it was at

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: least a most suspicious remark."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "On the contrary," said Holmes, "it is the brightest rift which I

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: can at present see in the clouds. However innocent he might be,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: he could not be such an absolute imbecile as not to see that the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: circumstances were very black against him. Had he appeared

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: surprised at his own arrest, or feigned indignation at it, I

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: should have looked upon it as highly suspicious, because such

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: surprise or anger would not be natural under the circumstances,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: and yet might appear to be the best policy to a scheming man. His

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: frank acceptance of the situation marks him as either an innocent

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: man, or else as a man of considerable self-restraint and

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: firmness. As to his remark about his deserts, it was also not

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: unnatural if you consider that he stood beside the dead body of

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: his father, and that there is no doubt that he had that very day

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: so far forgotten his filial duty as to bandy words with him, and

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: even, according to the little girl whose evidence is so

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: important, to raise his hand as if to strike him. The

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: self-reproach and contrition which are displayed in his remark

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: appear to me to be the signs of a healthy mind rather than of a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: guilty one."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: I shook my head. "Many men have been hanged on far slighter

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: evidence," I remarked.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "So they have. And many men have been wrongfully hanged."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "What is the young man's own account of the matter?"

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "It is, I am afraid, not very encouraging to his supporters,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: though there are one or two points in it which are suggestive.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: You will find it here, and may read it for yourself."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: He picked out from his bundle a copy of the local Herefordshire

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: paper, and having turned down the sheet he pointed out the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: paragraph in which the unfortunate young man had given his own

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: statement of what had occurred. I settled myself down in the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: corner of the carriage and read it very carefully. It ran in this

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: way:

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Mr. James McCarthy, the only son of the deceased, was then called

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: and gave evidence as follows: 'I had been away from home for

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: three days at Bristol, and had only just returned upon the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: morning of last Monday, the 3rd. My father was absent from home at

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the time of my arrival, and I was informed by the maid that he

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: had driven over to Ross with John Cobb, the groom. Shortly after

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: my return I heard the wheels of his trap in the yard, and,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: looking out of my window, I saw him get out and walk rapidly out

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: of the yard, though I was not aware in which direction he was

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: going. I then took my gun and strolled out in the direction of

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the Boscombe Pool, with the intention of visiting the rabbit

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: warren which is upon the other side. On my way I saw William

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Crowder, the game-keeper, as he had stated in his evidence; but

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: he is mistaken in thinking that I was following my father. I had

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: no idea that he was in front of me. When about a hundred yards

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: from the pool I heard a cry of "Cooee!" which was a usual signal

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: between my father and myself. I then hurried forward, and found

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: him standing by the pool. He appeared to be much surprised at

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: seeing me and asked me rather roughly what I was doing there. A

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: conversation ensued which led to high words and almost to blows,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: for my father was a man of a very violent temper. Seeing that his

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: passion was becoming ungovernable, I left him and returned

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: towards Hatherley Farm. I had not gone more than 150 yards,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: however, when I heard a hideous outcry behind me, which caused me

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: to run back again. I found my father expiring upon the ground,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: with his head terribly injured. I dropped my gun and held him in

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: my arms, but he almost instantly expired. I knelt beside him for

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: some minutes, and then made my way to Mr. Turner's lodge-keeper,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: his house being the nearest, to ask for assistance. I saw no one

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: near my father when I returned, and I have no idea how he came by

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: his injuries. He was not a popular man, being somewhat cold and

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: forbidding in his manners, but he had, as far as I know, no

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: active enemies. I know nothing further of the matter.'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The Coroner: Did your father make any statement to you before

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: he died?

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Witness: He mumbled a few words, but I could only catch some

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: allusion to a rat.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The Coroner: What did you understand by that?

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Witness: It conveyed no meaning to me. I thought that he was

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: delirious.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The Coroner: What was the point upon which you and your father

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: had this final quarrel?

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Witness: I should prefer not to answer.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The Coroner: I am afraid that I must press it.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Witness: It is really impossible for me to tell you. I can

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: assure you that it has nothing to do with the sad tragedy which

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: followed.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The Coroner: That is for the court to decide. I need not point

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: out to you that your refusal to answer will prejudice your case

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: considerably in any future proceedings which may arise.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Witness: I must still refuse.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The Coroner: I understand that the cry of 'Cooee' was a common

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: signal between you and your father?

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The Coroner: How was it, then, that he uttered it before he saw

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: you, and before he even knew that you had returned from Bristol?

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Witness (with considerable confusion): I do not know.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "A Juryman: Did you see nothing which aroused your suspicions

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: when you returned on hearing the cry and found your father

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: fatally injured?

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Witness: Nothing definite.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The Coroner: What do you mean?

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Witness: I was so disturbed and excited as I rushed out into

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the open, that I could think of nothing except of my father. Yet

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: I have a vague impression that as I ran forward something lay

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: upon the ground to the left of me. It seemed to me to be

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: something grey in colour, a coat of some sort, or a plaid perhaps.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: When I rose from my father I looked round for it, but it was

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: gone.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'Do you mean that it disappeared before you went for help?'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'Yes, it was gone.'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'You cannot say what it was?'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'No, I had a feeling something was there.'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'How far from the body?'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'A dozen yards or so.'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'And how far from the edge of the wood?'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'About the same.'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'Then if it was removed it was while you were within a dozen

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: yards of it?'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "'Yes, but with my back towards it.'

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "This concluded the examination of the witness."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I see," said I as I glanced down the column, "that the coroner

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: in his concluding remarks was rather severe upon young McCarthy.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: He calls attention, and with reason, to the discrepancy about his

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: father having signalled to him before seeing him, also to his

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: refusal to give details of his conversation with his father, and

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: his singular account of his father's dying words. They are all,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: as he remarks, very much against the son."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Holmes laughed softly to himself and stretched himself out upon

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the cushioned seat. "Both you and the coroner have been at some

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: pains," said he, "to single out the very strongest points in the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: young man's favour. Don't you see that you alternately give him

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: credit for having too much imagination and too little? Too

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: little, if he could not invent a cause of quarrel which would

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: give him the sympathy of the jury; too much, if he evolved from

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: his own inner consciousness anything so outre as a dying

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: reference to a rat, and the incident of the vanishing cloth. No,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: sir, I shall approach this case from the point of view that what

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: this young man says is true, and we shall see whither that

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: hypothesis will lead us. And now here is my pocket Petrarch, and

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: not another word shall I say of this case until we are on the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: scene of action. We lunch at Swindon, and I see that we shall be

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: there in twenty minutes."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: It was nearly four o'clock when we at last, after passing through

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: the beautiful Stroud Valley, and over the broad gleaming Severn,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: found ourselves at the pretty little country-town of Ross. A

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: lean, ferret-like man, furtive and sly-looking, was waiting for

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: us upon the platform. In spite of the light brown dustcoat and

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: leather-leggings which he wore in deference to his rustic

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: surroundings, I had no difficulty in recognising Lestrade, of

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Scotland Yard. With him we drove to the Hereford Arms where a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: room had already been engaged for us.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I have ordered a carriage," said Lestrade as we sat over a cup

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: of tea. "I knew your energetic nature, and that you would not be

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: happy until you had been on the scene of the crime."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "It was very nice and complimentary of you," Holmes answered. "It

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: is entirely a question of barometric pressure."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Lestrade looked startled. "I do not quite follow," he said.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "How is the glass? Twenty-nine, I see. No wind, and not a cloud

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: in the sky. I have a caseful of cigarettes here which need

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: smoking, and the sofa is very much superior to the usual country

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: hotel abomination. I do not think that it is probable that I

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: shall use the carriage to-night."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Lestrade laughed indulgently. "You have, no doubt, already formed

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: your conclusions from the newspapers," he said. "The case is as

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: plain as a pikestaff, and the more one goes into it the plainer

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: it becomes. Still, of course, one can't refuse a lady, and such a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: very positive one, too. She has heard of you, and would have your

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: opinion, though I repeatedly told her that there was nothing

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: which you could do which I had not already done. Why, bless my

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: soul! here is her carriage at the door."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: He had hardly spoken before there rushed into the room one of the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: most lovely young women that I have ever seen in my life. Her

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: violet eyes shining, her lips parted, a pink flush upon her

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: cheeks, all thought of her natural reserve lost in her

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: overpowering excitement and concern.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Oh, Mr. Sherlock Holmes!" she cried, glancing from one to the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: other of us, and finally, with a woman's quick intuition,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: fastening upon my companion, "I am so glad that you have come. I

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: have driven down to tell you so. I know that James didn't do it.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: I know it, and I want you to start upon your work knowing it,

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: too. Never let yourself doubt upon that point. We have known each

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: other since we were little children, and I know his faults as no

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: one else does; but he is too tender-hearted to hurt a fly. Such a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: charge is absurd to anyone who really knows him."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I hope we may clear him, Miss Turner," said Sherlock Holmes.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "You may rely upon my doing all that I can."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "But you have read the evidence. You have formed some conclusion?

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Do you not see some loophole, some flaw? Do you not yourself

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: think that he is innocent?"

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I think that it is very probable."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "There, now!" she cried, throwing back her head and looking

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: defiantly at Lestrade. "You hear! He gives me hopes."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Lestrade shrugged his shoulders. "I am afraid that my colleague

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: has been a little quick in forming his conclusions," he said.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "But he is right. Oh! I know that he is right. James never did

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: it. And about his quarrel with his father, I am sure that the

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: reason why he would not speak about it to the coroner was because

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: I was concerned in it."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "In what way?" asked Holmes.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "It is no time for me to hide anything. James and his father had

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: many disagreements about me. Mr. McCarthy was very anxious that

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: there should be a marriage between us. James and I have always

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: loved each other as brother and sister; but of course he is young

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: and has seen very little of life yet, and--and--well, he

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: naturally did not wish to do anything like that yet. So there

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: were quarrels, and this, I am sure, was one of them."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "And your father?" asked Holmes. "Was he in favour of such a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: union?"

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "No, he was averse to it also. No one but Mr. McCarthy was in

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: favour of it." A quick blush passed over her fresh young face as

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Holmes shot one of his keen, questioning glances at her.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Thank you for this information," said he. "May I see your father

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: if I call to-morrow?"

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I am afraid the doctor won't allow it."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "The doctor?"

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Yes, have you not heard? Poor father has never been strong for

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: years back, but this has broken him down completely. He has taken

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: to his bed, and Dr. Willows says that he is a wreck and that his

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: nervous system is shattered. Mr. McCarthy was the only man alive

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: who had known dad in the old days in Victoria."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Ha! In Victoria! That is important."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Yes, at the mines."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Quite so; at the gold-mines, where, as I understand, Mr. Turner

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: made his money."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Yes, certainly."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Thank you, Miss Turner. You have been of material assistance to

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: me."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "You will tell me if you have any news to-morrow. No doubt you

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: will go to the prison to see James. Oh, if you do, Mr. Holmes, do

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: tell him that I know him to be innocent."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I will, Miss Turner."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I must go home now, for dad is very ill, and he misses me so if

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: I leave him. Good-bye, and God help you in your undertaking." She

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: hurried from the room as impulsively as she had entered, and we

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: heard the wheels of her carriage rattle off down the street.

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I am ashamed of you, Holmes," said Lestrade with dignity after a

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: few minutes' silence. "Why should you raise up hopes which you

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: are bound to disappoint? I am not over-tender of heart, but I

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: call it cruel."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "I think that I see my way to clearing James McCarthy," said

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: Holmes. "Have you an order to see him in prison?"

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Yes, but only for you and me."

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY

text: "Then I shall reconsider my resolution about going out. We have

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: NA

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
text: "Then let us do so. Watson, I fear that you will find it very

story: ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY
